cluster.title: Columbia University student detained by ICE, later released, amid protests and political statements.

synthesis.narrative:
## State of the Story: Columbia Student Detained and Released by ICE

### Key Facts Established

On Thursday, February 26, 2026, Department of Homeland Security agents detained Columbia University student Elaina Aghayeva (also referred to as Elmina Aghayeva) from a university residential building around 6:30 a.m. [1][4]. The student was released the same day after New York City Mayor Zohran Mamdani spoke with President Trump about the case [1][4].

### The Detention

DHS officials confirmed that ICE arrested Aghayeva, identifying her as "an illegal alien from Azerbaijan, whose student visa was terminated in 2016 under the Obama administration for failing to attend classes" [1][6]. According to DHS, "The building manager and her roommate let officers into the apartment. She has no pending appeals or applications with DHS" [1][6].

### Disputed Entry Methods

Columbia University and federal officials present conflicting accounts of how agents gained building access. Columbia's acting president Claire Shipman stated that "federal agents made misrepresentations to gain entry to the building to search for a 'missing person'" [1][4]. Manhattan Borough President Brad Hoylman-Sigal alleged that ICE "used a phony missing persons bulletin" about a 5-year-old girl and "purposefully deceived" campus personnel [1]. New York Governor Kathy Hochul stated that "ICE agents didn't have the proper warrant, so they lied to gain access to a student's private residence" [5]. However, DHS has not directly addressed these allegations about misrepresentation [4].

### The Student's Profile

Aghayeva is described as a neuroscience researcher and content creator with over 100,000 followers on Instagram and TikTok, known for "studytok" content including study sessions and morning routines at Columbia [5]. She posted on Instagram Stories during her detention, writing "Dhs illegally arrested me. Please help" [5].

### Political Intervention and Release

Mayor Mamdani announced on social media that after speaking with President Trump, he was informed that Aghayeva "will be released imminently" [1][4]. Columbia University confirmed her release shortly after 4:15 p.m. ET [1]. Following her release, Aghayeva posted that she was "on the way home but was in 'complete shock over what happened'" [5].

### Campus Response

Students protested on Columbia's campus following news of the detention, though no incidents or arrests were reported [4]. The university emphasized that "all law enforcement agents must have a judicial warrant or judicial subpoena to access non-public areas of the University, including housing, classrooms, and areas requiring CUID swipe access" [4][6].

### Broader Context

This incident occurs amid Trump's expanded immigration enforcement efforts, which have become "a national flashpoint" [1]. Columbia University has been under scrutiny from the Trump administration, with the Education Department previously stating the school violated federal antidiscrimination laws, leading to a $200 million settlement to restore federal funding [1].

deepAnalysis.historicalContext: This incident occurs within the broader context of Trump's renewed immigration enforcement policies, which mirror and expand upon his first-term approach. Columbia University has been a particular target of the Trump administration, recently settling for $200 million after the Education Department found violations of federal antidiscrimination laws. The case also reflects ongoing tensions between federal immigration enforcement and sanctuary jurisdictions like New York City, where local officials routinely oppose federal deportation efforts. The use of alleged deceptive practices to gain building access echoes historical concerns about ICE tactics during workplace and residential raids, which have been criticized by immigrant rights advocates and local officials across multiple administrations.
implications: Sets precedent for federal immigration enforcement on university campuses, potentially affecting international student enrollment and campus security policies
Demonstrates continued tension between federal immigration policy and local sanctuary jurisdiction protections
Highlights vulnerability of international students with expired or terminated visas, regardless of current academic standing
May prompt legislative or policy responses regarding warrant requirements for immigration enforcement in educational settings
Could influence university policies on cooperation with federal law enforcement and building access protocols
Raises questions about the role of social media influence in immigration cases, given Aghayeva's significant online following
May affect diplomatic relations with Azerbaijan and other countries whose students study in the U.S.
Could impact Columbia University's federal funding relationships and regulatory compliance requirements
